Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Snowpit location was in a relatively wind sheltered area. Above the snowpit location, much of the east facing terrain was significantly wind affected/ 1F snow/ from the recent storm and not optimal for skiing. It seemed like all other aspects around the Mt. Henderson area (S, W and N) had less surface wind affect.
No avalanche activity observed.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
We experienced 3 significant collapses- all 10m in diameter or larger, and the group of friends we met up with reported another 5 other significant collapses. These collapses were during repeatedly recycling the same skin track.
On a nearby NE aspect around 9100' (on Miller Ridge )we were finding a HS 70-80cms, and also had one significant collapse there too.
No avalanche activity to report. Minimal wind effect of new snow, great early season skiing on certain slopes above 9k'.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: After a dry and mild fall, Montana and Idaho entered winter, receiving 70-100cms (2-3 feet) of snow in the past 5 days in the Lost Trail Pass area. The storm has settled well most locations, however there is a layer of concern on steeper, shaded, northerly aspects above 7500'. Test results showed propagation around a meter down in two study pits 145cm deep (ECTP22 @47cm SC/Q1; ECTP28@47cm SC/Q1). Though generally conditions are good, keep an eye on those slopes. And be aware, early season conditions still persist !

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, localized;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug by Doug, Ray, Barbo, Ellie, Mac, and Matty. Preseason. No ski tracks or prior mitigation. Other pits in the vicinity showed similar test results with little variability.
Skiable snow starts around 8500'.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Slightly wind scoured snowpit location.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope;
We skied slope; Poor pit location;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit location just below Arrowhead Bowl, brutal, strong winds deterred us from going higher. Rain on snow event seemed to have solidified the bottom 20cm of snow. Strong westerly winds were blowing down all east facing basins. Noticed recent avalanche debris in October Bowl to the south. Snowpack is still thin in places it has not been wind drifted, variable conditions.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very layered snowpack with many different crusts. Natural avalanche, looked cornice triggered on different N/NE aspect near ridge line at ~ 10,000 ft. elevation. Snow pit layers of most concern are two Knife crusts near the surface (80 cm and 76 cm above ground respectively) and a buried layer of small facets 25-45 cm above the ground.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Recent activity: Fresh drifts broke naturally on wind loaded slopes, high on Saddle Peak.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Westerly winds were blowing today, moving lots of snow along the high ridgelines. Snowpit was in a relatively deeper snowpack location. Was typically finding about HS 40-60cms. Near and along the ridgeline, I was getting lots of subtle collapsing and cracking (not making much sound- muffled by the new snow?), but the cracks were traveling 30' or more in many places.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Warming season eval. Notably robust & cool pack, combined with lack of alarming fracture character, suggests that >1 24-hr period w/o freeze may be required to result in instability concerns
